Navigation
Name Recipes/Common/Crawl
Synopsis Crawl a file system and collect files with given extension
Description A Web Crawler is a program that browses web pages in a systematic manner. Here we present a crawler for files in a file system, although it can easily be extended to browse the web as well.
Examples 
module demo::common::Crawl

import IO;
import String;

public loc catenate(loc basedir, str entry){ 
   baseuri = basedir.uri;
   if(!endsWith(baseuri, "/"))
   	  baseuri += "/";
   return basedir[uri=baseuri + entry];
}

public list[loc] crawl(loc dir, str suffix){ 
  res = [];
  for(str entry <- listEntries(dir)){
      loc sub = catenate(dir, entry);
      if(endsWith(entry, suffix)) { 
         res += [sub]; 
      }
      if(isDirectory(sub)) {
         res += crawl(sub, suffix);
      }
  };
  return res;
}
We start with defining a helper function catenate () that concatenates a new file name to a location basedir that is assumed to be a directory. First a check is done (using Rascal:endsWith) whether the uri in basedir already ends with a slash character. If not, that is added. Next, the basedir is returned, with its uri replaced. See Rascal:Location for details.

Next, we define the actual crawl function (). It takes two arguments:
  • The directory dir where the crawl should start.
  • The suffix of the files we are looking for.
The crawler now simply lists all entries in the current directory using Rascal:listEntries and adds all files that end we the given suffix to the result. If an entry is itself a directory, it is crawled by a recursive call to crawl.

Let's now crawl the demo files used in this course: 
rascal>import demo::common::Crawl;
ok
rascal>files = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
list[loc]: [|std://library/demo/basic/Ackermann.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Bottles.rsc|,|std://library/dem»
o/basic/Bubble.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/BubbleTest.rsc|,|std://library/demo/basic/Factorial....
This list can be the starting point for further investigation, for instance, to compute the number of files; 
rascal>import List;
ok
rascal>size(files);
int: 86
or to compute the total number of lines in these files: 
rascal>import IO;
ok
rascal>(0 | it + size(readFileLines(f)) | loc f <- files);
int: 3322
This above example uses a Rascal:Reducer expression.

Finally, we can look for the largest files. First import some libraries we will need. 
rascal>import Relation;
ok
rascal>import Set;
ok
Create a relation aux of pairs: 
rascal>aux = {<f, size(readFileLines(f))> | loc f <- files};
rel[loc, int]: {
  <|std://library/demo/lang/MissGrant/DesugarResetEvents.rsc|,8>,
  <|std://library/demo/Rules/ConcreteBool.rsc|,37>,
  <|std://library/demo/common/LiftTest.rsc|,32>,
  <|std://library/demo/lang/...
Now determine the maximum length (using Rascal:size), by taking the maximum of the Rascal:range of aux: 
rascal>m = max(range(aux));
int: 154
and now Rascal:invert aux and use Rascal:Subscription to find the tuples with the maximum value as first element. 
rascal>invert(aux)[m];
set[loc]: {|std://library/demo/lang/Func/Eval3.rsc|}
